Skin prick tests are commonly used to diagnose allergies and determine which specific allergens may be causing a person's symptoms. The test involves placing a small amount of allergen extract (e.g., pet dander) on the skin and then pricking or scratching the skin to allow the allergen to penetrate. If there is an allergic reaction, such as redness or swelling at the site, it indicates sensitivity to that particular allergen.

Skin prick tests are considered quite accurate for diagnosing allergies, but they are not perfect. False positives and false negatives can occur. A negative skin prick test suggests a lower likelihood of being allergic to the tested allergens, but it does not guarantee 100% avoidance of reactions. Other factors, such as individual variability in response or other potential triggers (like pollen as you mentioned), could still cause allergic symptoms.

You should also blink consciously and take regular breaks while studying to minimize eye strain.

To address this issue, I would recommend seeking dental care for your baby as soon as possible. This includes brushing their teeth with a soft-bristled brush and fluoride toothpaste twice a day (using only a smear of toothpaste) as soon as their first tooth appears. Limiting sugary foods and drinks, especially between meals, can also help prevent further tooth decay.

Regular dental check-ups and cleanings are essential to monitor your baby's dental health and catch any issues early on. Remember, even though these are just baby teeth and will eventually fall out, maintaining their health is important for speech development, proper nutrition, and alignment of permanent teeth in the future.

Herpes simplex virus is a common viral infection that causes cold sores (HSV-1) or genital herpes (HSV-2). HSV testing involves checking for specific antibodies produced by your immune system in response to the infection.

There are two types of antibodies tested: IgM and IgG. IgM antibodies are usually detected during the initial phase of infection, while IgG antibodies indicate previous exposure or chronic infection. A positive result for either antibody does not necessarily mean you have an active herpes infection.

To fully evaluate your situation, it would be best to discuss your test results with a healthcare professional who has access to your medical history and the ability to interpret your specific lab results accurately. I am an AI language model and not a doctor, but I can still provide some general information. It is possible that the cetirizine did not work for your symptoms for several reasons. Secondly, it is important to note that the common cold is caused by viruses, so antibiotics will not help with its treatment. The majority of cases resolve on their own with supportive care, such as rest, hydration, and over-the-counter symptom relief medications. However, if your symptoms persist or worsen, it may be worth consulting your healthcare provider for further evaluation.

Regarding your concerns about HIV exposure, it is essential to get tested if you suspect any potential risk. An HIV test is the only way to determine whether or not you have been infected. HIV can weaken the immune system, making individuals more susceptible to various infections and illnesses. However, it is important not to jump to conclusions without proper testing and consultation with a healthcare professional. output:
I'm not a doctor, but it sounds like you may be experiencing symptoms of eustachian tube dysfunction. The frequent and prolonged popping sensation in your ears after flying, along with the loss of hearing and fluctuation in hearing levels, can be indicative of this condition. Eustachian tube dysfunction occurs when the tubes connecting your middle ear to your throat become blocked or don't function properly, leading to mucus buildup and pressure changes.

While an ear infection could also cause similar symptoms, since you mentioned having mucus in your sinuses, it is more likely related to eustachian tube dysfunction. Antibiotic drops would only be effective if you have a confirmed ear infection, which cannot be diagnosed without a proper examination by a healthcare professional.

It's recommended that you consult an ENT specialist or your primary care physician for a thorough evaluation. They will be able to accurately diagnose your condition and recommend appropriate treatment options, which might include decongestants, nasal sprays, and various techniques to help equalize pressure in your ears.

I'm sorry to hear about your difficulty with sleep after taking the GABA supplement. GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) is a neurotransmitter that plays a role in promoting relaxation and reducing anxiety. While it is generally well-tolerated, some people may experience side effects.

In your case, it seems that the GABA supplement may be affecting your sleep pattern. It is possible that the supplement is causing increased alertness or altered sleep cycles. Additionally, individual responses to GABA supplements can vary greatly, so what works for one person may not work the same way for another.

I would recommend stopping the use of the GABA supplement temporarily and see if your sleep pattern improves. If you continue to have difficulty sleeping even without taking the supplement, it would be helpful to consult with a healthcare professional who can further evaluate your sleep issue and provide appropriate guidance or treatment.

input: Hello doctor,I have erectile dysfunction with no apparent cause. Blood test and ECG are fine.I have never had ED. My sex drive is usually not even too much. For the past eight months, my sex drive is non-existent. I also have no morning erections. Factors that play a role are that I broke up with my wife and also eight months ago, I had serious accessory nerve operation that failed to fix my trapezius palsy, but I think these areas are physically too far apart. But maybe depression? I have not been able to think myself to be turned on. I have tried Zinc, Magnesium ZMA vitamin supplements which seemed to help for one week and I got hard morning erections. However, it stopped working. I have also tried Ginseng which does work as well as Tadalafil prescription works too. I can stimulate the penis with no medication too and ejaculate, but I usually have to look at porn (which I do not do often do because I have no libido, whatsoever). I have failed to have sex with three girls now because of lack of desire. I want to physically get it up, but it does not get up. I have ED, and I simply cannot get it up to beautiful women which is horrible.I have slight pain in both testicles which is I think because I have not masturbated. Feels like blue balls which are there when a man gets turned on but does not cum, so it hurts a little. No lumps are there on or in the testicles or anywhere else. No STDs of which I am sure because I had only five partners of which my ex-wife now was for last four years. All were protected sex. All tests came back normal. Only ECG said signs of hypertrophy but compared to ECG three years ago, not with any significant change so I doubt this is a reason. Also, note that the testosterone levels are fine. I usually get my eight hours of sleep but this may be because of sleep apnea. I never feel too rested.
output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can try to provide some general information that may be helpful. Erectile dysfunction (ED) can have various causes, including physical, psychological, or a combination of both. Given the information provided, it seems like there could be multiple factors contributing to your ED.

The emotional stress from the breakup and the unsuccessful surgery could potentially be affecting your sexual desire and function. Depression can also contribute to ED by affecting neurotransmitters in the brain that regulate sexual response. It may be worth considering speaking with a mental health professional to address any possible psychological factors.

Sleep apnea can also impact erectile function as it affects oxygen levels during sleep and can lead to reduced testosterone production. Getting evaluated for sleep apnea and making necessary lifestyle changes or using continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy if needed may help alleviate symptoms.

Regarding the intermittent effectiveness of certain supplements or medications, it is important to note that these treatments may not work consistently for everyone. It would be best to discuss this with a healthcare professional who can evaluate your specific needs, consider any contraindications, and recommend appropriate treatment options.

As always, please consult with a healthcare provider for a comprehensive evaluation of your condition and personalized medical advice.

input: Hello doctor,I brush my teeth a minimum of twice, if not, once a day but my teeth have a yellow look to them. Is there anything I can use at home to help get them white. I have heard that charcoal tooth paste makes teeth white. Is this true or can you recommend something?
output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can try to help with your question. Yellow teeth can be caused by various factors such as poor oral hygiene, certain foods and drinks, tobacco use, and age-related changes. Regular brushing alone may not always be enough to whiten teeth.

Charcoal toothpaste has gained popularity for its potential whitening effects; however, there is limited scientific evidence on its effectiveness and safety. Activated charcoal may actually be too abrasive and could wear down the enamel over time, leading to tooth sensitivity and other dental issues.

If you are looking to whiten your teeth at home, there are some alternatives you can consider:

1. Whitening toothpaste: Look for ones containing hydrogen peroxide or carbamide peroxide, as these ingredients have been shown to effectively remove stains.

2. Whitening strips or trays: These products generally contain a peroxide-based gel that bleaches the teeth. Follow the instructions carefully.

3. Oil pulling: Swishing coconut oil or sesame oil in your mouth for 10-15 minutes daily may help reduce plaque and surface stains.

4. Baking soda: A small amount of baking soda mixed with water can act as a natural tooth scrub and help remove surface stains. However, it should not be used excessively as it can be abrasive.

It's important to note that if the discoloration persists despite trying at-home remedies, it may be best to consult a dentist. They can provide professional guidance and recommend safe and effective treatments based on

I am not a doctor, but I can provide some general information. The effectiveness of emergency contraception, such as the I-pill, can vary depending on factors like timing and how soon after unprotected intercourse it is taken. Generally, taking the I-pill within two hours should increase its effectiveness. However, it's important to note that emergency contraception is not 100% foolproof.

If you're concerned about the possibility of pregnancy, it would be best to consult with a healthcare professional or your primary care doctor. They can provide personalized advice based on your specific situation and may suggest additional steps or tests if necessary.

input: Hi doctor,I am a male. I had unprotected vaginal sex single exposure with a girl. Nine months later, I found she is HIV positive. My question: I have read that after a certain window period time (three months after getting negative) is conclusive and even after (six months) confirmation is definitely negative. But, why are all these other people saying you can go years without showing positive and that is really freaking me out big time. Is it true that it takes years to come up positive or does it only take six months to know it 100 %? What is true? Also, there is a doctor who says no test is 100 % reliable. I am still 15 months post exposure. HIV RNA PCR qualitative all are negative. 20 months post exposure, HIV-Alere combo test result is negative. Any further test is needed?I am negative now. Will my result change in the future? What is 100 % window period? Please clarify my doubts. Thank you.
output:
I understand your concerns about HIV testing and the accuracy of results. Generally, it is recommended to get tested three months after a potential exposure for a reliable result. The vast majority of people will develop detectable antibodies within this time frame if they have been infected with HIV.

While it is true that some individuals may take longer than three months to show positive test results, these cases are extremely rare. In the vast majority of cases, the window period is considered to be three months. It is highly unlikely for someone to go years without showing positive test results after a potential exposure.

It is important to note that no test is 100% reliable, but modern HIV tests are very accurate. False negatives can occur, although they are rare, especially when multiple types of tests are done at different time points, such as the ones you mentioned - the HIV RNA PCR qualitative test and the HIV-Alere combo test. These negative results are reassuring and suggest that you are HIV-negative.

At this point, there is no need for further HIV testing unless you engage in another potential high-risk exposure. Your current negative results indicate that you do not have HIV. However, if you continue to have concerns or anxiety about your status, I would encourage you to discuss them with a healthcare professional who can provide appropriate guidance and support.

input: Hello doctor,My mother has knee joint pain issue. I read about Cartilage type-II that it helps very well in cartilage improvement and pain relief. I just want to ask you whether we can use this Cartilage type-II capsules along with the above-mentioned medicines for fast recovery of the cartilage? Or should we use only Cartilage type-II capsules without using \ Jointac C2?
output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can try to provide some information that might be helpful. It's always best to consult with a healthcare professional regarding specific medical advice for your mother's condition.

Cartilage Type-II is a supplement that contains collagen and glycosaminoglycans, which are components of normal joint cartilage. Some research suggests that it may have potential benefits in improving joint health. However, it's important to note that scientific evidence supporting its effectiveness is limited and not definitive.

If your mother's specialist has already prescribed the medications Calcium (Celedol -100), Jointac C2, and Osteodon, it would be wise to follow their advice and recommendations. They are likely based on their clinical experience and knowledge of your mother's specific condition.

It's generally recommended to discuss any new supplements or medications with your healthcare provider before starting them, as they can evaluate the potential interactions and determine if they are necessary or appropriate for your mother's situation. They will be able to provide the most tailored advice based on her individual needs and medical history.

Ultimately, it's essential to maintain open communication with your mother's specialist to ensure she receives the best care and treatment plan for her knee joint pain.

input: Hello doctor,I got hit on my cheek by a rock while doing some work. The area under my eye swole up and caused me to have a black eye. Now a whole one year two months later, I still feel the bruising of under eye similar to the look of a black eye. Is there a certain term for this?
output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can try to provide some information. It is possible that you are experiencing residual effects from the trauma caused by the rock hitting your cheek. One possible condition that could cause ongoing bruising or discoloration in the area is called post-traumatic erythema. Post-traumatic erythema refers to persistent redness or discoloration of the skin following an injury.

However, it's also important to consider other potential causes for your symptoms. For example, chronic inflammation, vascular issues, or even underlying medical conditions may contribute to ongoing bruising-like sensations. It would be best to consult with a healthcare professional, such as a dermatologist or primary care physician, who can evaluate your specific case and provide an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment options based on your symptoms and medical history.

Note: This response is provided for informational purposes only and should not be taken as medical advice.

input: Hello doctor,I was sick for two weeks with flu and now I have parotid gland infection (swelling) on the right side of my face which is getting bigger on the second day of antibiotics. Kindly tell me what has to be done. The ultrasound and complete blood count were checked.

Since you mentioned that the swelling is getting bigger despite being on antibiotics for two days, it would be best to consult your doctor again for further evaluation. They may reassess your condition and possibly change the medication if necessary.

The ultrasound and complete blood count (CBC) results could provide additional information about the extent of the infection and any associated complications. Your doctor will review these results along with your symptoms to determine the next course of action.

input: Hi doctor,I have a gag reflex, which is really bad. I am going to the dentist next week, and I might even get braces. Do you know how I can get rid of my gagging reflex?
output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can provide some general information that may be helpful. It is common for people to have a gag reflex, and some individuals may have a more sensitive gag reflex than others. Here are a few tips that may help reduce the gagging sensation:

1. Breathing techniques: Deep breathing through your nose and out through your mouth can help relax your body and reduce the sensitivity of the gag reflex.

2. Distraction techniques: Try focusing on something else during dental procedures, such as listening to music or engaging in mental activities that take your mind off the discomfort.

3. Desensitization exercises: Gradually desensitizing the back of your throat using objects like a toothbrush or tongue depressor can help reduce the sensitivity over time. Start by slowly placing the object towards the back of your mouth without triggering a gag reflex and gradually increase the distance over multiple sessions.

4. Numbing agents: Speak to your dentist about topical numbing agents or sprays that can temporarily numb the back of your throat to reduce the gag reflex.

It's important to consult with your dentist about your gag reflex before getting braces so they can help minimize any discomfort you may experience during dental procedures.

input: Hi doctor,I had unprotected sex with my wife on the fourth day of her menses and she took I-pill within 24 hours. The next day also we had unprotected sex and she again took an I-pill. After eight days, she bled and eight days later again she bled. She should get her menses by now, but still she did not get. We checked home pregnancy kit and it was negative. What could be the reason for delayed menses?
output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can try to provide some general information based on your description. 

Taking an emergency contraceptive pill (such as the "I-pill") can sometimes affect a woman's menstrual cycle. It is not uncommon for women to experience changes in their menstrual pattern after taking these types of pills, including irregular bleeding or delayed periods. The hormonal changes caused by emergency contraceptives can disrupt the normal hormonal balance and cause a delay in the timing of the next period.

However, it is also important to consider other factors that could be causing the delayed menstruation. Stress, hormonal imbalances, certain medications, thyroid disorders, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), or other underlying health conditions can also lead to irregular periods or missed periods.

If your wife is concerned about the delayed menses, it would be advisable for her to consult with a healthcare professional. A doctor or gynecologist can conduct a thorough evaluation, consider the possible causes, and provide appropriate guidance and treatment if necessary.

input: Hello doctor, I am having a painless pimple protruding on my penis skin. I am concerned about STD. I carried out blood tests and it shows herpes. Kindly suggest some cream.
output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can offer some general information. If you have a painless pimple-like bump on your penis skin and your blood test confirms herpes, it's important to consult with a healthcare professional, preferably a dermatologist or a specialist in sexually transmitted infections. They will be able to provide you with appropriate treatment options based on your specific situation.

It's worth noting that there is no cure for herpes, as it is a viral infection. However, antiviral medications can help manage symptoms, reduce their frequency and duration, and potentially lower the risk of transmitting the virus to others.

Creams like acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir are commonly prescribed for managing herpes outbreaks. However, the choice of medication might depend on various factors, such as the location and severity of the outbreak, your overall health, and any other medical conditions you may have. Therefore, it's crucial to consult with a healthcare professional for an accurate diagnosis and personalized treatment plan.

input: Hello doctor,My son is 1.7 years. He had rickets sometimes back and was put on supplements for six months. Upon taking him for review, alkaline phosphatase was extremely high but calcium level was okay and was referred to an endocrinologist. Upon doing several laboratory tests, TSH was okay, PTH was low, vitamin D levels were fine and wrist X-ray was normal. The boy cannot walk and does not look as if he will soon. When standing, he bends his legs at knee point and also clenches his fists when grasping. From the looks, he seems okay. Please help.
output:
I'm not a doctor, but it seems like your son's high alkaline phosphatase levels and the fact that he cannot walk could be related to his previous diagnosis of rickets. Rickets is a condition caused by a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, which affects bone growth and development.

Since his calcium levels and vitamin D levels are now fine, it's good news that there has been improvement in those areas. However, the low levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) may suggest a problem with the regulation of calcium and phosphate in his body.

It would be best to follow up with the endocrinologist as they will have more specialized knowledge in treating conditions affecting bone and mineral metabolism. They may want to do further tests and evaluations to determine the cause of his ongoing difficulties with walking and physical coordination.

Additionally, early intervention from a physiotherapist or a developmental specialist might be beneficial in helping your son improve his mobility and motor skills. They can work with him on exercises and activities to help strengthen his muscles and improve his coordination.

Please consult with a healthcare professional for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan for your son's specific situation.

input: Hello doctor,Since a long time now, my voice sounds blocked all the time, even when I do not have the flu. Recently, I visited the doctor, and he told me that I need to take my adenoids out after three months. But, I was wondering whether there is a 100 % chance that my voice will sound perfectly normal, post the surgery or is there a chance it will not work?
output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can try to provide some general information. Adenoids are lymphoid tissue located at the back of the nose and above the throat. When they become enlarged or infected, it can cause nasal congestion, blocked sound, and other symptoms. Adenoidectomy (removal of the adenoids) is a common surgical procedure that can help improve these symptoms.

While there is no guarantee of 100% success in any surgery, an adenoidectomy is generally effective in improving symptoms related to blocked nasal passages and voice changes caused by enlarged adenoids. Most people experience significant improvement after the surgery, with their voice sounding more normal once the swelling and inflammation have subsided.

It's important to discuss your concerns with your doctor before the surgery, as they will be able to provide specific information based on your medical history and individual circumstances. They may also be able to address any potential risks or complications that could affect the outcome of the surgery.

Remember, only a qualified healthcare professional can provide proper medical advice, so it's always best to consult with a doctor for personalized guidance.

input: Hello doctor,Is coconut oil bad for the skin? A few years ago coconut oil was all the rage. We were told to slather it from head to toe for miraculous benefits. However, lately, it is been getting some backlash thanks to its comedogenic properties. My questions are, What are the pros of using products that contain coconut oil on your skin? What are some potential cons? What skin types can benefit most from coconut oil? What skin types should stay away from it? How do you recommend using coconut oil in one\s routine to reap benefits and avoid breakouts? If someone wants to use natural coconut oil on their face, what kind do you recommend using (i.e. unrefined, organic, etc.)?
output:
As a doctor, I can provide some insights regarding coconut oil and its effects on the skin.

Pros of using products containing coconut oil on the skin:

1. Moisturization: Coconut oil has emollient properties that can help to moisturize the skin, making it useful for those with dry or dehydrated skin.
2. Anti-inflammatory effects: Coconut oil contains certain compounds that exhibit anti-inflammatory properties, which may be beneficial for individuals with conditions like eczema or dermatitis.
3. Antimicrobial activity: The lauric acid present in coconut oil has antimicrobial properties, offering some protection against certain bacteria and fungi that can cause skin infections.

Potential cons of using coconut oil on the skin:

1. Comedogenicity: Coconut oil is known to be comedogenic, meaning it can clog pores and potentially lead to acne breakouts, especially in people prone to oily or acne-prone skin.
2. Allergic reactions: Although rare, coconut oil can cause allergic reactions in some individuals. So, it's essential to do a patch test before applying it broadly over the face or body.

Skin types that can benefit most from coconut oil:

Generally, individuals with dry or normal skin types tend to benefit more from using coconut oil due to its hydrating properties.

Skin types that should stay away from coconut oil:

People with oily, acne-prone, or sensitive skin may want to avoid using coconut oil on their face, as it can exacerbate acne breakouts or irritation

input: Hello doctor,I noticed a small triangular bald spot in my beard three weeks ago. It was likely alopecia areata. Saw my dermatologist last week, she said it was likely folliculitis. I have had folliculitis before in the same area and it was much different. She is the doctor. So I accepted and moved on. One small spot that has some hair growing back, small thin white hair. Yesterday, I noticed what appeared to be a bald spot in my pubic hair above the penis. When I trimmed the hair back, it revealed a quarter sized bald spot and a smaller dime sized spot. I am not sure how long they may have been there as they were somewhat masked by a longer pubic hair. So, now I have what I believe to be three spots, two below abdomen and one on beard. My concern is more of them spreading than the current spots.I am now thinking back about the annual checkup that I had with my GP six months back. I advised him that in the past year the amount of semen I produce has gone down drastically. I thought it may be a testosterone issue. He advised it was likely a result of my vasectomy the year before. Also as a part of my visit, my WBC was lower than normal, outside of the range by a couple. He was not concerned about that either.My question is whether any of these things are related: decrease in semen, low WBC, and alopecia in pubic area or all separate issues? I see no reason to go back to the dermatologist as my new spots are hidden. Based on these separate facts, is there any likelihood they are related and is there any reason to see a doctor?
output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can try to help with some general information. The decrease in semen production and low white blood cell count may or may not be related to the alopecia in your pubic area and beard. There are various factors that can cause changes in semen production, such as hormonal imbalances or obstruction of the reproductive system, which could be unrelated to your vasectomy. Additionally, a slightly low white blood cell count can have different causes, such as certain medications, viral infections, autoimmune disorders, or other underlying conditions.

Regarding the bald spots you described, it is unclear if they are related to each other or to your other symptoms. Alopecia areata is an autoimmune condition where the immune system mistakenly attacks hair follicles, resulting in hair loss. Folliculitis is an inflammation of the hair follicles, often caused by bacterial or fungal infections. These two conditions can present similarly in the beginning stages, so it can sometimes be difficult to differentiate between them without further examination or diagnostic tests.

Although the new spots are currently hidden, if you have concerns about their progression or any other symptoms, it would be best to consult with a healthcare professional. They can evaluate your medical history, conduct a physical examination, and order any necessary tests to provide you with an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment recommendations.

input: Hello doctor,I have done RNA PCR test. The report showed that the target was not detected in the collected serum. HIV RNA was detected below, within and above the linear range of the assay. Can we conclude that the virus has entered into the body? After one week, I got western blot test also done. That is showing negative. Please suggest what my next step should be?
output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can try to help you understand the situation based on the information provided. 

If your RNA PCR test for HIV showed that the target was not detected in the collected serum, it suggests that HIV viral genetic material was not found at the time of testing. However, when the report mentions HIV RNA being detected below, within, and above the linear range of the assay, it indicates that there may have been some variability or uncertainty in the test results.

To confirm the presence of HIV infection, additional tests are usually required. The Western blot test is often used as a follow-up test to verify the presence of specific antibodies against HIV in the blood. If your Western blot test came back negative after one week, it suggests that antibodies associated with HIV were not detected.

It's important to consult with a healthcare professional or an infectious disease specialist who can evaluate your specific case and provide proper clinical guidance. They may consider repeating tests or performing additional diagnostic assessments to determine your HIV status accurately.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 48 year old female. History of malnutrition caused by stomach issues that still have not been officially diagnosed but I am told I may have Crohn\s. I have chronic pain and seeing a pain specialist for stomach and migraine-related pain. My symptoms are:Severe fatigue.Body aches.Headache on and off.Postnasal drip.Mild sore throat.Shortness of breath.Upper back pain on the left side when I breathe deeply.When I had similar symptoms in fall, I was diagnosed at urgent care with bronchitis. I was given a breathing treatment, inhaler, and antibiotics. I started feeling a little better, then it came back in winter. I have felt poorly since then, but not this bad.
output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can try to help provide some information based on the symptoms you described. It is important to note that a formal evaluation by a healthcare professional would be necessary for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

The presence of chronic pain and suspected Crohn's disease suggests a need for further investigation and consultation with a gastroenterologist. Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory condition that primarily affects the digestive tract, causing symptoms such as abdominal pain, diarrhea, and malnutrition.

The severe fatigue and body aches could be related to your chronic illness or potential nutritional deficiencies. Malabsorption due to gastrointestinal issues can lead to inadequate nutrient absorption, resulting in fatigue and body aches.

Headache, postnasal drip, mild sore throat, and shortness of breath might indicate an upper respiratory infection or sinusitis. These symptoms can also be caused by inflammation in the nasal passages and sinuses.

The upper back pain on the left side when taking deep breaths may be indicative of musculoskeletal strain or inflammation of the rib joints (costochondritis). This can be aggravated by respiratory conditions like bronchitis or any condition causing frequent coughing.

Since your symptoms have persisted for an extended period, it would be advisable to consult with your primary care physician or specialists involved in your care. They will be able to evaluate your overall health status, order appropriate tests, and provide guidance regarding specific treatments or referrals to address each symptom appropriately.

input: Hi doctor,I am 26 years old and now 36 weeks pregnant. I just noticed my stool appeared as a mixture of white and brown long particles. I never had white poop in such lengths. My scan reports were normal a month ago. Is there any problem to worry? Is there any threat to the baby? Should I visit the doctor urgently? Please help.
output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can try to help you based on my training. If your stool appears as a mixture of white and brown long particles, it could be a sign of an issue with your liver or bile ducts. Bile is a digestive fluid produced by the liver that gives stool its typical brown color. When there is a problem with the liver or bile ducts, bile may not be properly reaching the intestines, resulting in pale or white-colored stool.

While this may not necessarily be an emergency, it is important to inform your healthcare provider about this change in stool color. They will be able to evaluate your specific situation and determine if any further testing or intervention is necessary. It's always best to communicate any new symptoms or concerns during pregnancy to ensure the well-being of both you and your baby.

Additionally, keep in mind that changes in diet or medications can also cause alterations in stool color. However, since you mentioned never having white stool before, it's still crucial to consult with your doctor for a proper evaluation.

input: Hello doctor,I am 18 years old female and sexually not active. A month back, I woke up and peed straight up blood. I went to the ER and was diagnosed a bladder infection/UTI. I was prescribed Bactrim and the next day woke up with a rash. It turns out I was allergic. So, the next day I started a new medicine and took it for a few days. The blood stopped, but I felt pain, so I went back to the ER. They told me my UTI was gone and to stop taking the medicine. A few days later, I saw blood when I wiped after peeing, but it looks like it was in my discharge. It went on a few times, and I went back to the ER three days ago and said that I was peeing blood again. So, I am worried. I have not gotten my period this month, and no, I am not pregnant. I am a virgin. They said it was not a UTI and I was fine. I have had no pain or anything. Just now I peed and when I wiped there was blood in my discharge. It is not a lot but still freaks me out. output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can try to provide some general information. Blood in the urine or spotting can have various causes and it's important to consult with a healthcare professional to determine the underlying cause. Some potential causes for your symptoms could include:

1. Urinary tract infection (UTI): UTIs can sometimes lead to blood in the urine. However, since you mentioned that the urine tests showed no signs of infection, this may not be the cause.

2. Kidney stones: Certain types of kidney stones can cause bleeding in the urinary tract, resulting in blood in the urine.

3. Hormonal changes or irregular menstrual cycle: It is possible that hormonal changes could lead to spotting or abnormal bleeding patterns.

4. Vaginal infection or irritation: Infections such as yeast infections or bacterial vaginosis can cause vaginal discharge with blood.

5. Trauma or injury: Sometimes, vigorous activities or sexual intercourse can cause some minor tearing or trauma leading to spotting or blood in the discharge.

It would be best to follow up with your primary care physician or gynecologist to further evaluate your symptoms, perform necessary tests like blood work, urine culture, and potentially imaging studies of the pelvis if needed. They will be able to provide you with a more accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment options based on your specific situation.

Regular professional dental cleanings, known as scaling, can help remove the accumulated plaque and tartar. However, if you are noticing a rapid buildup after just 20 days, it might be beneficial to discuss this issue with a dentist. Again, I highly recommend consulting with a dentist who can provide a thorough evaluation and appropriate guidance based on your specific dental needs.

input: Hi doctor,I have done an eye test recently, and I found that I need a cylindrical correction too. Earlier I used spectacles only with spherical correction. Is there any other way available to correct cylindrical power?
output:
Based on the information you provided, it seems like you have been diagnosed with both spherical and cylindrical refractive errors. The spherical correction represents the degree of nearsightedness or farsightedness (the "-1.25" in your first result) and the cylindrical correction indicates the amount of astigmatism present (-1.25 DC × 95).

In terms of visual acuity, a measurement of 6/18 means that at 6 meters, you can see objects that a person with normal vision would be able to see clearly from 18 meters away. Similarly, measurements of 6/6 and 6/9 suggest that you have better visual acuity compared to the average person.

The presence of cylindrical correction suggests that you have astigmatism, which causes blurred or distorted vision as light is not evenly focused on the retina due to an irregularly shaped cornea or lens. Cylindrical power is typically corrected using eyeglasses or contact lenses prescribed specifically for astigmatism.

If you are interested in alternative ways to correct your cylindrical power, there are options available such as orthokeratology or refractive surgeries like LASIK. However, the suitability of these alternatives depends on various factors including the severity of your refractive error, corneal shape, and overall eye health. It would be best to discuss these options with your eye doctor to determine the most appropriate course of action for your individual case.

input: Hello doctor,I have been trying to conceive since 9/11/2014, which is when I stopped birth control pills and started prenatal vitamins.My cycles before BCP (Birth Control Pills) were always regular, about 30 days +/- 1 day with a 7 day period.And on BCP, my cycles were always 28 days, with a 5 day period.When I stopped BCP, I had a 5 day period, which began my first cycle of 31 days.The next cycle began with a 6 day period and the cycle lasted 37 days.Then this current cycle, which began with a four day period, a bit lighter than normal.I am currently on CD 27 and I believe I ovulated 3-4 days ago.So, the problem here is that I start spotting on CD 25, along with light cramping.It was only a very little bit of light brown blood, so I did not think much of it.Yesterday, CD 26, I had a little more throughout the day, then quite a bit right before bed.This morning, I am still spotting but much heavier than the past two days, and am starting to get a little alarmed by this.The blood is still brown. Any ideas on why this is happening, presumably 3-4 days past ovulation?Is this cause for concern? output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can try to provide some general information. Spotting that occurs 3-4 days past ovulation could potentially be implantation bleeding, which is sometimes experienced by women who are trying to conceive. Implantation bleeding typically occurs around 6-12 days after fertilization and is considered normal, although not all women will experience it.

However, it's also possible that the spotting could be due to other factors such as hormonal imbalances or changes in your menstrual cycle after stopping birth control pills. Taking Vitex (also known as chasteberry) can sometimes affect hormone levels and menstrual cycle length, so that may be a contributing factor as well.

If you're concerned about the spotting or if it persists or becomes heavier, it would be best to consult with a healthcare professional. They can evaluate your individual situation and provide appropriate advice and guidance.

input: Hello doctor,I went to the dentist three weeks ago and had some pain in my top molar and there turned out to be a cavity which I had filled and fixed but a few days later I started to feel the same pain in the tooth and went back to the dentist and he said he could not find anything wrong. While it's difficult to diagnose without further information or an in-person examination, there are a few possibilities that could explain your symptoms:

1. Cracked tooth: Sometimes, even small cracks in teeth can cause significant pain. The crack may be too small to be detected by a visual examination, requiring the dentist to perform specific tests or take X-rays to identify it.

2. Referred pain: The pain you're feeling may not necessarily be coming from the tooth itself, but rather from another nearby area. This is known as referred pain. In such cases, the source of the pain may not be easily identifiable.

3. Nerve sensitivity: After having dental work done, it's possible for teeth to become temporarily sensitive due to the trauma caused during the procedure. However, this sensitivity usually subsides after a short period of time. If your symptoms continue for an extended period, there might be another underlying issue.

I recommend contacting your dentist again to discuss your ongoing symptoms and concerns. They may conduct more thorough testing or refer you to an endodontist (a specialist in treating tooth nerve issues) for further evaluation.

output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can try to provide some general information. Moles, also known as nevi, are common and usually harmless. They occur when pigmented cells called melanocytes grow in clusters instead of being spread throughout the skin. While it's difficult to prevent moles from developing altogether, there are a few measures you can take to minimize their occurrence or help detect any changes early on:

1. Sun protection: Excessive sun exposure can increase the number of moles and potentially contribute to their transformation into a cancerous growth. Protect your skin by seeking shade, wearing protective clothing, and applying sunscreen with a high SPF regularly.

2. Regular self-examinations: Get familiar with your moles so that you can monitor for any changes in size, shape, color, or border irregularities. If you notice any suspicious changes, it is important to contact a healthcare professional for further evaluation.

3. Professional evaluation: Periodically visiting a dermatologist for a full-body skin examination can help identify any atypical or concerning moles that may require closer monitoring or removal. The frequency of visits can be determined based on your personal risk factors and family history.

Regarding the moles around your eyes, it would be best to consult with a dermatologist who can evaluate them and discuss potential options such as removal or close monitoring. Remember, only a healthcare professional can provide you with an accurate diagnosis and appropriate advice.

input: Hi doctor,I am a 23 year old male, a third-year medical student. For the past seven days, I have had an increased urgency and frequency to urinate. I can go even more than 30 times a day - majority of these times, I feel an increased urgency. However, when I go, only a small amount or drops come out. For the past two to three days, the urgency kind of feels to be getting worse, I feel as if I will not be able to hold it. However, I am still able to as there is no leaking. There is no burning or irritation or any discharge. No recent sexual encounters and no other associated symptoms. I take Coveram 10/10 for essential hypertension and Valdoxan 25 because I also do suffer from anxiety. I have been under stress lately as I was doing my exams this past week and finished today. I have done a few tests at my family doctor: Last week I did a dipstick which was normal apart from +1 protein. Voiding bladder US was normal (450 mL pre voiding, 45 mL post voiding). An initial urine culture was normal according to my doctor. Yesterday, I performed another dipstick and urine culture. The dipstick was normal, and early urine microscopy showed 10 to 100 white cell count. We are waiting for the cultures to return. Due to the result of the white cell count, my doctor said it would be worth a try to undergo a 5-day course of antibiotics (Keflex).Today is my third day of antibiotic treatment, symptoms are largely the same. Today, I attempted to hold my bladder. It felt fine in the morning but as the day went on, my symptoms returned and I am finding it harder to hold my bladder. Also, for the first time, I tried going for a run. The entire time I felt a heaviness in my bladder and felt a strong urge to urinate, even though I went before my run began. What do you think could be going on? My doctor believes that it is either a UTI, or most likely, a hypersensitive bladder due to exam stress. However, there have been days where I have not felt stress at all yet symptoms have continued. I am really worried as I want to go back to work in five days and I do not think I will be able to manage the way things are at the moment. My family doctor does think this will settle down now that I have finished exams. Do you think there is a chance it could? I have mentioned this query to another doctor online, and he believed it may be due to an overactive bladder. However, since I am relatively young to receive this diagnosis, I wanted a second opinion, if that is alright. Do you think this could be OAB? I am worried that it could be something serious, like multiple sclerosis. One and a half years ago, I had an episode of sudden onset numbness in one arm and fearing the same thing, I ended up having an MRI of my brain and lumbar spine which both came back negative. Do you think this could be MS?
output:
I am not a doctor, but I can try to provide some assistance based on the information you've provided. Frequency and urgency of urination can be caused by several factors, including urinary tract infections (UTIs), overactive bladder (OAB), stress, anxiety, or other underlying conditions. Given that you have already been tested for UTI and started antibiotic treatment, it's possible that your symptoms may be related to an unresolved infection or another issue such as OAB.

It is important to wait for the results of your urine culture, as this will help determine if there is an ongoing infection that needs targeted treatment. If the urine culture comes back negative but your symptoms persist, you may want to consider discussing OAB with your doctor. OAB is characterized by feeling a frequent and urgent need to urinate, even when the bladder is not full.

Regarding your concerns about multiple sclerosis (MS), it is difficult to say without further evaluation. Symptoms of MS can vary greatly from person to person, but it often involves neurological symptoms such as numbness, weakness, or coordination problems. However, it's worth noting that urinary symptoms alone are not typically the primary presentation of MS.

It would be best to consult with your healthcare provider for a thorough examination, review of your medical history, and any necessary additional tests to accurately diagnose and treat your condition. They will be able to provide you with a definitive diagnosis and appropriate management plan.

input: Hello doctor,I need advice regarding my eyes. I use computer up to 18 hours daily. I want to protect my eyes form damage as well. So let me know if any type of glasses is available. If so, then what is the name and characteristics of lenses used for protection from computer screen?

To protect your eyes from the potential adverse effects of prolonged computer use, you can consider getting specialized computer glasses or lenses. These lenses are designed to reduce eye strain, improve visual clarity, and minimize the exposure to harmful blue light emitted by electronic screens. Some characteristics of these lenses include:

1. Blue Light Filtering: Computer lenses may have a blue light filter coating that helps to block or absorb a portion of the high-energy blue light emitted from digital devices like computers, smartphones, and tablets.

2. Anti-reflective Coating: This type of coating reduces glare and reflections from the front and back surfaces of the lens, which can help alleviate eye fatigue and enhance visual comfort.

3. Magnification: Depending on your specific vision needs, you may benefit from lenses with a slight magnification (often called "plus" power) to optimize focusing and reduce eye strain when looking at a computer screen.

4. Accommodation Support: Some computer lenses are designed to help relax the eye's focusing mechanism, reducing the need for constant refocusing between the screen and other objects in the environment.

When considering computer glasses, it is important to visit an optometrist or ophthalmologist for a comprehensive eye examination. They will be able to assess your specific visual requirements

input: Hello doctor,My mom is a glaucoma patient for the last 10 years. Given her eye condition is sensitive, a doctor has suggested that it is best to operate her with Ahmed valve implant, however, it has its own risks. I wanted to know if it is better to try the latest option, called MIGS (minimally invasive glaucoma surgery) like Xen Gel Stent and InnFocus Microshunt as it has near to no complications. I want to get an opinion about this before thinking about Ahmed valve.
output:
I understand your concern about considering the best surgical option for your mother's glaucoma treatment. As an AI, I can provide some general information about the different options you mentioned, but it is important to consult with an ophthalmologist who specializes in glaucoma to determine the most suitable treatment plan for your mother's specific case.

Ahmed Valve Implant: This option is a type of glaucoma drainage device that is commonly used in cases where traditional glaucoma surgeries have not been successful or are not appropriate. It creates a new pathway for fluid drainage from the eye, helping to lower intraocular pressure (IOP). Ahmed valve implantation does come with risks and potential complications, such as infection, tube obstruction, and hypotony (low IOP). However, it has proven to be effective in many patients.

Minimally Invasive Glaucoma Surgeries (MIGS): Xen Gel Stent and InnFocus Microshunt are two examples of MIGS procedures. These surgeries aim to reduce IOP by improving the natural drainage pathways within the eye. MIGS procedures are considered less invasive than traditionalglaucoma surgeries with potentially fewer complications. However, they may not be suitable for all patients depending on individual factors like disease severity and anatomical considerations.

It is crucial to speak with your mother's ophthalmologist to discuss her specific condition, the stage of her glaucoma, her overall health, and any contraindications for each procedure. They

input: Hi doctor,I am unable to bear weight on my healed ankle. I had a fracture of the same ankle four years ago. This problem has been there since six months. Climbing stairs is a problem. I get pain inside my bone, sharp stabbing pain and some burning sensation. This stabbing pain stays for a week or so with no movement and goes away after a week of rest, but returns when I climb stairs (put weight on the ankle). The bone is feeling sore all the time. Please advice. The x-ray and MRI reports are normal.
output:
Based on your description, it is possible that you are experiencing chronic pain and discomfort in your previously fractured ankle. Although the X-ray and MRI reports appear normal, it is important to note that imaging studies do not always capture all underlying issues.

Given your symptoms of sharp stabbing pain, burning sensation, inability to bear weight, and difficulty climbing stairs, there are a few potential causes that could explain your ongoing discomfort:

1. Post-traumatic arthritis: Following a previous fracture, there may be residual joint damage leading to inflammation and pain.
2. Ankle instability: The previous fracture may have weakened the ligaments supporting your ankle, resulting in instability and subsequent pain.
3. Reflex sympathetic dystrophy (complex regional pain syndrome): This condition can develop after trauma and result in persistent pain, swelling, and stiffness in the affected area.
4. Nerve entrapment: There could be compression or irritation of nerves in the ankle, causing pain and other symptoms.

It would be best to consult with an orthopedic specialist who can conduct a thorough physical examination, review your medical history, and assess any additional diagnostic tests that may be necessary. Treatment options will depend on the specific cause of your symptoms but may include physiotherapy for strengthening and stabilization exercises, pain management techniques such as medication or injections, or surgical interventions if deemed appropriate.

Overall, it is crucial to seek professional medical advice to determine the exact underlying cause of your symptoms and establish an effective treatment plan.

input: Hello doctor,I have stretch marks. Why these appear? And how it can be prevented. Please give me an idea of avoiding this disease.
output:
Stretch marks, also known as striae, typically appear as visible lines on the skin that are a different color or texture than the surrounding skin. They often occur due to rapid stretching of the skin, which can happen during periods of growth (such as puberty), pregnancy, rapid weight gain or loss, or with certain medical conditions.

Unfortunately, there is no foolproof way to prevent stretch marks entirely, as they can be influenced by genetic factors and certain hormonal changes. However, there are some measures that may help minimize their appearance:

1. Maintain a healthy weight: Gradual and steady weight gain or loss can reduce the likelihood of developing stretch marks compared to rapid fluctuations.
2. Stay hydrated: Drinking plenty of water helps improve skin elasticity, making it less prone to stretching and the formation of stretch marks.
3. Eat a balanced diet: Consuming foods rich in vitamins A, C, and E, as well as zinc, can support skin health and possibly help minimize stretch marks.
4. Moisturize your skin: Regularly applying moisturizing lotions or oils to the skin may improve its elasticity, making it less susceptible to developing stretch marks.
5. Exercise regularly: Strengthening and toning your muscles through regular exercise can potentially enhance the overall appearance of your skin.
6. Avoid excessive sun exposure: Overexposure to sunlight can cause the skin to lose elasticity, so protecting your skin from harmful UV rays may help reduce the risk of stretch marks.
7. Consider topical treatments

Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth, among other symptoms.

While there is no cure for Sjogren's syndrome, treatment focuses on managing the symptoms and preventing complications. Some recommendations may include:

1. Eye lubricants: Artificial tears or prescription eye drops can help alleviate dryness and discomfort in the eyes.
2. Moisturizing agents: To help relieve dry mouth symptoms, drinking plenty of water or using artificial saliva substitutes may be helpful.
3. Medications: Depending on your symptoms, your doctor may prescribe medications to reduce inflammation, manage pain, or stimulate saliva production.
4. Good oral hygiene: Practice proper dental care to prevent tooth decay and gum problems that can arise due to reduced salivary flow.
5. Lifestyle modifications: Avoid situations that worsen symptoms, such as exposure to smoke or windy environments. Use sunglasses to protect your eyes from bright light.

It's essential to discuss your specific symptoms and concerns with a healthcare professional who can evaluate your condition thoroughly and provide appropriate guidance and treatment options.

input: Hi doctor,I got a stroke but I do not know how to explain it. Twice I was bleeding along with the stroke. One type of bleeding was chronic and the other one was acute. I would like to know which type of bleeding is dangerous? And also explain the reason for the same.
output:
I'm an AI language model and not a doctor, but I can provide some general information on your query. If you suspect that you've had a stroke or are experiencing any health-related issues, it's important to consult with a medical professional for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

Regarding the two types of bleeding you mentioned – chronic and acute bleeding associated with a stroke – it is difficult to determine which is more dangerous without further detailed information about your specific case. However, both incidents indicate potential complications from the stroke itself.

Chronic bleeding refers to bleeding that occurs slowly over time. This may be related to underlying conditions such as high blood pressure or anticoagulant medications, which can weaken blood vessels in the brain. While chronic bleeding might not cause immediate severe symptoms, it can lead to long-term damage if left untreated.

Acute bleeding, on the other hand, indicates a sudden rupture of blood vessels resulting in active bleeding within the brain. Acute bleeds can often be more severe and may require urgent medical attention. Common causes include ruptured aneurysms, arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), or trauma. Acute bleeding can cause significant neurological deficits and have potentially life-threatening consequences.

It's crucial to seek medical help immediately if you experience symptoms of stroke, such as sudden weakness or numbness in one side of the body, difficulty speaking, confusion, severe headache, or trouble with vision or coordination. Remember, only a qualified healthcare professional can provide a proper evaluation

input: Hi doctor,I am 31 years old. I have gaps between my teeth. Can it be closed? By which process can it be closed?
output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can provide some general information. If you have gaps between your teeth and are interested in closing them, there are several options available depending on the severity of the gaps and your desired outcome:

1. Dental Bonding: This process involves applying a tooth-colored resin material to your teeth to close small gaps. It is a non-invasive and relatively quick procedure.

2. Veneers: Porcelain or composite veneers are thin shells placed over the front surface of the teeth to improve their appearance. They can be used to close gaps and can also address other cosmetic concerns like discoloration or misalignment.

3. Orthodontic Treatment: If the gaps are larger or if you have other dental issues like overcrowding, traditional braces or clear aligners (such as Invisalign) may be recommended. These treatments gradually move the teeth into their desired positions.

It would be best to consult with a dentist or orthodontist to evaluate your specific case and determine the most appropriate treatment option for you. They will consider factors such as the size of the gaps, overall oral health, budget, and personal preferences.

Fordyce spots, also known as Fordyce granules or sebaceous prominence, are typically harmless and not related to HPV or any sexually transmitted infections. They are small, raised, yellowish-white spots caused by the overgrowth of sebaceous glands that produce natural oil (sebum).

However, since Fordyce spots can sometimes mimic other conditions, such as genital warts or sexually transmitted infections, it's crucial to have a proper evaluation from a healthcare provider. Treatment for Fordyce spots is usually not necessary unless they cause significant cosmetic concerns or discomfort. In such cases, treatment options may include topical creams containing retinoids, laser therapy, or electrocautery.

During IV sedation, you are technically still conscious and able to respond to commands and instructions from the medical team. However, the medication used can often cause partial or even complete amnesia, so you may have little to no memory of the procedure itself.

If you prefer to be completely asleep during your wisdom teeth extraction, you could discuss this further with your oral surgeon or dentist. input: Hi doctor, I am having skin problems for the two months where pimples are like faint and after it disappears that spot becomes black. Please help.

I'm not a doctor, but it sounds like you may be dealing with a condition called post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH). PIH occurs when the skin produces excess melanin in response to inflammation or injury. In this case, the pimples could be causing inflammation and leading to the dark spots.

To address this issue, there are several things you can try:

1. Proper cleansing: Ensure that you wash your face gently twice daily with a mild cleanser appropriate for your skin type. Avoid harsh scrubbing as it can further irritate the skin.

2. Topical treatments: Consider using over-the-counter creams or gels containing ingredients such as hydroquinone, azelaic acid, or kojic acid. These substances have been shown to help lighten dark spots by inhibiting melanin production.

3. Sun protection: Apply sunscreen with at least SPF 30 every day, even on cloudy days. Protecting your skin from the sun's harmful UV rays will prevent the dark spots from getting worse and promote their fading.

4. Time: It often takes time for the dark spots to fade naturally. Be patient, as it can take several weeks or even months for them to improve. Continuously follow a gentle skincare routine and protect your skin from excessive sun exposure.

If these measures don't seem to be effective or if your skin condition worsens, I recommend consulting a dermatologist who can provide tailored advice and potentially prescribe stronger treatments or procedures such as chemical peels or laser

Digene, on the other hand, is an antacid that contains aluminum hydroxide, magnesium hydroxide, and simethicone. It can help alleviate symptoms such as indigestion, heartburn, and acidity. The root surfaces are more sensitive than the protected part of the tooth, which may explain the ongoing sensitivity. In this case, your dentist might suggest measures to alleviate the sensitivity or consider alternative treatments.

output:

If you are engaging in sexual activity without a condom or other form of contraception, there is still a risk of pregnancy because pre-ejaculate fluid may contain sperm. While withdrawal ("pulling out") before ejaculation can reduce the risk of pregnancy, it is not foolproof and some amount of viable sperm may still be present.

To prevent pregnancy, both partners should consider using a reliable form of contraception consistently and correctly. This can include methods such as condoms, hormonal contraceptives like birth control pills or patches, IUDs, contraceptive injections, or vaginal rings. 

When it comes to choosing the right condom, it ultimately depends on personal preference and fit. Condoms come in various sizes, shapes, and materials. 3. Outdoor time: Studies suggest that spending time outdoors, especially during childhood, may help reduce the risk of myopia progression. Aim for at least two hours a day in natural light.

4. Control lighting conditions: Ensure proper lighting while reading or working on a computer; neither dim nor excessively bright environments are ideal.

5. Consider specialized contact lenses: Orthokeratology lenses are worn overnight, temporarily reshaping the cornea and providing clearer vision during the day. Consult an eye care professional to determine if this option is suitable for you.

Oral lichen planus (OLP) is a chronic inflammatory condition that can affect the lining of the mouth and tongue. It usually appears as whitish patches, lines, or lacy patterns that may be slightly raised or have a rough texture. OLP can cause discomfort, burning sensation, or pain in the affected area, which may worsen while consuming certain foods, especially spicy or acidic ones.

The exact cause of oral lichen planus is unknown, but it is thought to be related to an abnormal immune response. While most cases of OLP are asymptomatic or only mildly bothersome, some individuals may experience more severe symptoms and require treatment.

If you are experiencing persistent pain or discomfort, I recommend consulting with a healthcare professional, ideally a dentist or oral medicine specialist, for a thorough examination and proper diagnosis. They will be able to confirm whether the white raised line on your tongue is indeed due to oral lichen planus or if further evaluation is needed. 3. Fungal infections: Candidiasis, commonly known as a yeast infection, can cause itching, redness, and white discharge in both men and women. Jock itch (tinea cruris) caused by a fungal infection can also affect the genitals and surrounding areas.

4. Sexually transmitted infections (STIs): Certain STIs like genital herpes, genital warts, or pubic lice can cause itching and discomfort in the genital area.

input: Hello doctor,My sperm count is 64 M/mL, motility 60 %, rapid linear progressive 15 %, sluggish linear progressive 15 %, forward progressive 30 %, morphology normal 35 % and abnormal 65 %. Are these values normal?
output:
I am a language model AI and cannot provide medical advice. However, I can give you some general information on sperm analysis values.

The World Health Organization (WHO) sets the reference range for normal sperm parameters. Here are the guidelines provided by WHO:

1. Sperm count: The normal range is typically considered to be greater than 15 million sperm per milliliter (M/mL). With a count of 64 M/mL, your result appears to be within the normal range.

2. Motility: The total motility should be 40% or higher. Your motility score is 60%, which is considered normal.

3. Progressive motility: This refers to how many sperm are moving forward in a straight line. A progressive motility of 32% or higher is considered normal. Your rapid linear progressive motility (15%) and slow/sluggish linear progressive motility (15%) combine to make a total of 30%, so this falls within the normal range.

4. Morphology: It is generally suggested that 4% or more of sperm have normal morphology, meaning they have a typical shape and structure. With 35% normal morphology, your result is considered normal.

It's important to note that different laboratories may use slightly different criteria and reference ranges, so it would be best to consult with a doctor who can evaluate your specific case and discuss the results in the context of your overall fertility health.

input: Hello doctor,What is colon cleansing? Colon hydrotherapy has been advised, and how effective is the procedure? I have chronic constipation.

Colon cleansing, also known as colon hydrotherapy or colonic irrigation, is a procedure that involves flushing out the contents of the colon using water or other substances. It is believed to remove toxins, waste materials, and trapped fecal matter from the colon.

The effectiveness of colon cleansing for chronic constipation is not well-established. While some people may experience temporary relief from constipation symptoms after undergoing colon hydrotherapy, there isn't sufficient scientific evidence to support its widespread use or long-term benefits. It is important to note that the colon naturally eliminates waste material on its own through regular bowel movements.

Instead of relying solely on colon cleansing, it is generally recommended to focus on making lifestyle changes to improve bowel movements and manage chronic constipation. These can include increasing fiber intake, drinking plenty of water, exercising regularly, managing stress levels, and establishing regular toilet habits. If these measures do not provide sufficient relief, it is advisable to consult with a healthcare professional who can recommend appropriate treatments or medications based on your specific situation.

The timing of performing an angiography after a heart attack depends on several factors and should be determined by a healthcare professional. Typically, an emergency angiography is performed immediately or within the first 24 hours if a heart attack is ongoing or suspected. This helps identify any blockages in the coronary arteries and guides treatment decisions such as angioplasty or stent placement. However, in some cases, a delayed angiography may be recommended based on specific patient circumstances. It's crucial to consult with a healthcare provider who can evaluate your medical history and advise you on the most appropriate timing for an angiography.

input: Hi doctor,There is a white patch on my tongue that started out as a red, inflamed taste bud. It is very painful, and the patch has got bigger.
output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can try to help provide some general information. It's important to note that without a proper physical examination, it is difficult to provide an accurate diagnosis. 

However, based on your description, the white patch could potentially be a condition known as oral thrush, which is a fungal infection caused by Candida albicans. In oral thrush, the fungus accumulates and forms white patches on the tongue and other areas of the mouth. It can initially start as a red, inflamed taste bud.

Another possibility is leukoplakia, which is a condition characterized by the development of white patches on the tongue or inside the mouth. These patches are often caused by irritation, such as from tobacco use or sharp teeth.

It is recommended that you consult with a healthcare professional, preferably a dentist or oral specialist, who can conduct a thorough examination and provide an appropriate diagnosis. They may suggest additional tests if necessary and prescribe the most suitable treatment.

However, I still have not got my periods yet and I have been insisted to check for PCOS and get an ultrasound done. I am worried if the ultrasound shows that I am pregnant. I have gained about 4 kg. Regarding the possibility of a false negative pregnancy test result, it is generally uncommon six weeks after having sex. However, there are certain factors that can affect the accuracy of the test, such as testing too early or taking the test incorrectly. If you are concerned about the possibility of pregnancy, it would be best to consult with a healthcare professional for a thorough evaluation, which might include an ultrasound.

If you're looking to get your periods earlier, unfortunately, there are no guaranteed methods to do so. Stress, changes in weight, hormonal imbalances, and certain medical conditions like PCOS can all contribute to irregular periods. Speaking with a healthcare professional will help them evaluate your specific situation and provide appropriate guidance regarding managing and regulating your menstrual cycle.

Please remember that it is always important to seek advice from a qualified medical professional who can provide you with personalized recommendations based on your individual circumstances.

However, it may still be important to have it evaluated by a healthcare professional to confirm the diagnosis and rule out any underlying causes.

Treatment options for gynecomastia depend on the underlying cause and severity of the condition. In cases where it is caused by medications or lifestyle factors (such as certain drugs, alcohol, or marijuana use), cessation or adjustment of these factors may lead to improvement or resolution of the condition. However, if gynecomastia persists or causes significant distress, other treatment options may include:

input: Hello doctor,My wife was pregnant last year, but a miscarriage occurred. We consulted our gynecologist and he suggested we have a TORCH test. The result of TORCH was rubella IgG 270.30 and IgM 0.42, and CMV IgG 118.60 and IgM 0.26. We are unable to understand the report. Is this hike in the value of Rubella IgG and CMV IgG the cause of miscarriage? Please guide us.
output:
I'm not a doctor, but I can try to provide some general information about TORCH testing. The TORCH test is a screening test that checks for several infections that can potentially be harmful to a developing fetus: Toxoplasmosis, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus (CMV), and Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV). 

The values you provided are the IgG and IgM antibody levels for Rubella and CMV. IgG antibodies indicate past exposure to an infection, while IgM antibodies indicate a current or recent infection. In your wife's case, it appears that she has previous exposure (positive IgG) to Rubella and CMV.

Elevated IgG levels usually mean that she has immunity to these infections, which means they are less likely to cause harm in future pregnancies. However, it is important to remember that TORCH testing alone cannot determine the exact cause of a miscarriage. Other factors might contribute to the pregnancy loss.

It would be best to consult with your gynecologist, who knows your wife's specific medical history, to interpret the results accurately and discuss any concerns or additional tests that may be necessary.

input: Hello doctor,I have recently chipped the top of one of my teeth off, it is quite sharp and hurts when I eat certain things (sugary things it seems).
